title: Given a field where 1+1 is not equal to  0, must (-1)(-1)=1? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, that’s true in all fields. There’s no particular need for the qualification. If [math]1+1=0,[/math] i.e. if [math]1=-1,[/math] that’s a field of characteristic two, and [math](-1)(-1) = (1)(1) = 1[/math]. We’ll assume all our numbers are drawn from field [math]\mathbb F[/math]. Let’s go back to the field axioms and prove our result from first principals. We need to prove a couple of basic algebra rules. Lemma: [math]a0 = 0a = 0[/math] Multiplication by zero gives zero. Proof: [math]a0 = a0 + 0 \quad[/math] def additive identity [math]a0 = a0 + ( a0 + -a0 ) \quad[/math] existence & def of additive inverses [math]a0 = ( a0 + a0) + -a0  \quad[/math] associativity [math]a0 = a(0+ 0) + -a0 \quad [/math]distributive law [math]a0 = a0 + -a0 \quad[/math] def identity ([math]0+0=0[/math]) [math]a0 = 0 \quad [/math] def additive inverse [math]\quad\checkmark[/math] [math]0a = 0 \quad [/math]Commutativity of multiplication [math] \quad\checkmark[/math] Even these simple proofs require some cleverness. Lemma: [math](-1)a = -a[/math] This says negation is the same as multiplication by -1. Proof: [math] (-1)a  +  1 a = (-1)a + 1 a  \quad [/math]reflexivity of equality [math](-1)a + a = (-1 + 1) a \quad [/math]def mult. identity, distributive law [math](-1)a + a = 0 a \quad[/math] def additive inverse [math](-1)a + a = 0  \quad [/math]by the first lemma [math](-1)a = -a \quad [/math]def additive inverse [math]\quad\checkmark[/math] OK, we’re ready to show: Theorem: [math](-1)(-1)=1[/math] [math]1 + -1 = 0 \quad [/math] Existence and definition of the additive inverse [math](-1)(1 + -1) = (-1)(0) \quad[/math] Multiplying equals by equals [math](-1)(1) + (-1)(-1) = 0 \quad[/math] Distributive law, Lemma above [math]-1 + (-1)(-1) =0 \quad[/math] def multiplicative identity [math]1 + (-1 + (-1)(-1)) = 1 + 0 \quad[/math] adding equals to both sides [math](1 + -1) + (-1)(-1) = 1  \quad[/math] Associativity, def additive identity [math]0 + (-1)(-1)=1 \quad[/math] def additive inverse [math](-1)(-1)=1  \quad[/math] def additive identity [math]\quad\checkmark[/math] It’s a lot of work to prove the obvious, but worth it to assure ourselves our foundations are strong.

Yes. In any field, [math]-1[/math] is the number [math]k[/math] such that [math]k+1=0[/math]. So then [math](k+1)(k-1)=0(k-1)=0[/math] as well. But expanding out the product, [math]0=(k+1)(k-1)=k^2-1[/math], proving [math]k^2=1[/math] or equivalently, [math](-1)(-1)=1.\qed[/math]
